title: Why did Newton assert that 'action at a distance' is an 'absurdity indicating lacking mental faculties in philosophical reasoning'? - Quora

response.answer_text: Maybe the question would be better asked… “Is non-contained energy a contestable theory or an established fact, and if not contestable, then why?” And provide this image for context?  What if there are immutable fundamental “Group-Wave” physical building blocks? And “energy”= time + motion (aka momentum).   From Einstein, and Newton and Mr (is the cat in the box there or not there)… (is the 1 amidst the surrounding 12 needed, or can it be worked without… in the right balance situation?) Create…mechanically generate, physically… a solid-unit-groupwaveshaped-building block based… Bohmian Pilot Wave / Quantum Field when in motion.   So maybe… the better question, to get the point across, is to not focus on “Forces”…maybe that weirds people out too much, because they know they can fall off things… so to suggest “forces don’t exist” is maybe to high a first hurdle? The weight of gravity and the gravity of the suggestion all being factors to weigh in.  So maybe the easier mental achilles heel is our imbedded notion of what the concept of “energy” actually is. Whether it can be formless and bodiless like Star Trek would suggest. (among others)…  So maybe asking…about “energy” (yes quotes)… is the better head shaker?? People can “see” themselves falling, cause “gravity”. But “energy” is more aethereal. Obviously not clearly defined by what is “is”, but only by what “it does, and can do”. Tough. Cracking the nuts.  To get to what’s inside, sometimes. I think pictures help.

I guess that he didn’t like it much and hated the fact that that was the way his gravity theory worked. Probably he would have liked Einstein’s General Relativity and various field theories. You gotta say the guy had good instincts. Einstein said that for Newton, the pages of nature were an open book.
